adverbs.description: amidships (not generally comparable, comparative more amidships, superlative most amidships)

entries.meaning: (nautical) In the middle of a ship, either longitudinally or laterally.
examples: [The U-boat captain] waited until the crosshairs lay directly amidships.
Two more torpedoes were fired; one ran erratic; the second hit amidships.
The saloon, instead of being at the stern, according to the old method of construction, is placed more amidships.
The main cabin, most amidships, was 8 feet 3 inches broad [...]

entries.meaning: (nautical) Usually in the line of the keel, but sometimes halfway between bow and stern; often contracted to “midships.” (FM 55-501).
(figuratively) On the flank, at a vulnerable place.
